Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will develop theoretical tools and analysis methods to apply to current and upcoming Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT)
total intensity and polarization data. Three specific analyses will be considered: the Cosmic Microwave Background lensing signal by foreground galaxy clusters, the large angle CMB lensing versus temperature cross correlation, and an extension and improvement of ACT's measurements of galaxy motions via the mean pairwise velocity of galaxy clusters. These three studies will advance the understanding of growth of structure in the universe and the nature of gravitation on cosmological scales.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, Dr. Kosowsky will organize a scientist-teacher partnership program in the Pittsburgh region, modeled on the successful NSF Graduate STEM Fellows in K-12 Education program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project partly supported three graduate students who worked on the Atacama Cosmology Telescope (ACT) collaboration. ACT is a custom-designed 6-meter telescope in the Chilean Andes, supported primarily by the NSF, which has been making maps of the microwave sky for the past decade. The students trained under this award contributed in various ways to the project: Simone Aiola became an expert in converting our raw data into maps of the sky, a computationally demanding task; Jerod Caligiuri contributed to data analysis extracting science conclusions from the sky maps; and Fernando Zago has worked on improving the way we identify and cut overly noisy signals from our raw data stream. The training of these three outstanding Ph.D. students at the University of Pittsburgh was the most tangible outcome of this grant.

Radiation from the sky at microwave frequencies is of particular interest, because most of it has propagated freely over nearly all of the 13.7-billion-year history of  the universe. The microwave sky today provides an image of a spherical section of the universe when it was far younger and simpler than it is today. Mapping this image, which is nearly uniform over the sky but contains subtle variations in intensity, allows us to determine the basic properties of the universe with high  precision. ACT was one of the three pioneering experiments (along with NSF-funded South Pole Telescope and the European Space Agency's Planck Satellite) to make  high-resolution maps giving precise determination of our basic model of cosmology.

During the period of this award, the ACT collaboration made a number of notable  discoveries. We made the first detection of microwave background lensing by galaxy clusters. A galaxy cluster is a single object, largely made of dark matter and hot gas, with visible galaxies comprising only about 1 percent of the total mass. The gravity from these huge objects is enough to slightly bend the path of the microwave radiation passing the cluster, leading to a distinctive alteration of the microwave background temperature pattern on the sky in the direction of the cluster. This signal was originally explored in three theory papers in 2004, one of which I co-authored. It is difficult to detect, because the distortion is tiny compared to the underlying  pattern of microwave background variations, around one millionth of a degree in temperature. This effect is much smaller than we can directly detect with any current microwave experiment. However, we managed a statistical detection by estimating the distortion around each of 25,000 galaxies, and then averaging them together. This result was not surprising, but it is significant because it showed for the first time that lensing of the microwave background is potentially an efficient way to estimate masses of galaxy clusters. This in turn is important because the number of clusters and their mass distribution evolves over time, and this evolution is very sensitive to the expansion rate of the universe. Measurements of cluster evolution  are one of the few ways we can probe the expansion rate, and thus gain information  about the mysterious "dark energy" which cosmologists now think dominates the total energy of the universe over the last 5 billion years of cosmic evolution. We anticipate that the initial measurements of ACT are the first step towards far more precise measurements over the next decade.

A second interesting discovery was the effect of massive black holes on their surrounding galaxies. Most large galaxies harbor giant black holes in their centers, and heated gas swirling around the black hole gives off prodigious amounts of energy before being swallowed up. This energy can be enough to significantly heat the gas in the rest of the galaxy, but it is very difficult to measure the gas  temperature directly. We made an indirect measurement by showing that the microwave background radiation passing through these galaxies has its intensity suppressed at lower frequencies. This effect, known as the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect, has been well explored in galaxy clusters, which are much larger and have hotter gas. In individual galaxies, the effect is too small to see. Again, we averaged together the signal from thousands of individual galaxies to see a mean effect. By comparing with theoretical models of the gas temperature of galaxies without any heating from a black hole, we showed that it is likely that 5 to 10 percent of the energy coming out of the black hole goes into heating the gas. This fraction is consistent with what has been assumed in large computer simulations of galaxy formation, in order to match observed galaxy properties. The results matched what I predicted with a former graduate  student in 2009 from these simulations. Gas heating is a crucial ingredient in understanding the formation and evolution of galaxies, because it is far harder to form stars from hot gas than from cold gas.
